title: 107_s2710
content: The Act is titled the "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" and introduces a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" introduces a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit is determined based on the amount paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year for qualified employee health insurance expenses, with the applicable percentage varying based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees. The "Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002" introduces a credit for small business employee health insurance expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit is determined based on the amount paid by the taxpayer during the taxable year for qualified employee health insurance expenses, with the applicable percentage varying based on the average annual rate of wages of qualified employees. If the average annual rate of wages exceeds $10,000, a percentage calculation is applied, with different calculations for employers with more than 10 qualified employees. The applicable percentage for the Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 is determined based on the number of qualified employees and their average annual rate of wages. For employers with more than 10 qualified employees, a specific calculation is applied to determine the percentage. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 determines the applicable percentage based on the number of qualified employees and their average annual rate of wages. For employers with not more than 50 qualified employees, the applicable percentage shall not be less than 5 percent. The Per Employee Dollar Limitation sets a maximum amount of $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage for qualified employee health insurance expenses. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 sets limits on insurance expenses for qualified employees, with a maximum of $2,000 for self-only coverage and $5,000 for family coverage. Employers are considered eligible based on the average number of employees in the previous years. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 sets limits on insurance expenses for qualified employees based on the average number of employees in the previous years. Employers must meet specific criteria regarding employee numbers to qualify. The Small Employer Tax Assistance for Health Coverage Act of 2002 limits insurance expenses for qualified employees based on the average number of employees in the current year. Qualified employee health insurance expenses are defined as amounts paid by an employer for coverage provided to at least 50% of qualified employees, excluding amounts paid under salary reduction arrangements. The term "health insurance coverage" is defined as per section 9832(b)(1), disregarding the last sentence of section 9832(b)(2). The term 'qualified employee' refers to an employee who works more than 30 hours per week for the employer, excluding those eligible for certain health plans or benefits under specific acts. The term 'qualified employee' refers to an employee who works more than 30 hours per week for the employer, excluding those eligible for specific health plans or benefits under certain acts, such as the Social Security Act, title XIX or XXI, chapter 89 of title 5, chapter 55 of title 10, chapter 17 of title 38, or any medical care program under the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. The term 'employee' excludes those under section 401(c)(1) but includes leased employees under section 414(n). 'Wages' are defined by section 3121(a) without any dollar limitation. Rules similar to section 52 apply, and no double benefits are allowed for qualified employee health insurance expenses. The provision prohibits double benefits for qualified employee health insurance expenses and includes a new employee health insurance expenses credit in the general business credit. Unused credits cannot be carried back before January 1, 2003. No portion of the unused business credit attributable to the employee health insurance expenses credit under section 45G can be carried back before January 1, 2003. The amendments made by this section apply to small business employee health insurance expenses incurred after December 31, 2002, for coverage established after the enactment of this Act.
